title: Ukraine war: Maternity hospital hit by Russian air strike
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky said people were trapped under the rubble following the attack.

title: Ukraine war: Chernobyl power supply cut off, says energy operator
description: Even without power there is no critical impact on safety, the UN nuclear watchdog says.

title: War in Ukraine: Russia soon unable to pay its debts, warns agency
description: Russia will soon be in a position where it is unable to pay its debts, says Fitch Ratings.

title: Ukraine: First Lady Olena Zelenska condemns Russian 'mass murder'
description: Olena Zelenska issues an impassioned plea to world media, focusing on Ukraine's children.

title: Man given genetically modified pig heart dies
description: The man died two months after operation, says the hospital that carried out the world-first surgery.

title: Ukraine: Five moments of human connection amid the war
description: Since Russia's invasion of Ukraine, moments of hope and music have emerged on social media.

title: Covid: Austria suspends compulsory vaccination mandate
description: The country was days away from enforcing compulsory vaccinations for almost all over-18s with fines.

title: Venezuela releases two jailed US citizens after talks
description: The two were released just days after a high-level US delegation met President Nicolás Maduro.

title: Guatemala Congress bans same-sex marriage
description: The law also increases the length of prison sentences for women who seek an abortion.

title: Australia floods: PM Morrison to declare a national emergency
description: The floods have been described as a "once in 500-years event" and have left 20 people dead.

title: Denmark says sorry to children of failed experiment
description: Six surviving Inuit Greenlanders taken from their families in 1951 speak about their ordeal.

title: 'We are not co-operating': Life in occupied Ukraine
description: Ukrainian cities are now occupied by Russian troops, and residents are not making them feel welcome.

title: A Russian woman considers leaving her country behind
description: As Western companies leave Russia, Moscow residents consider what will happen to their jobs and the economy.

title: War in Ukraine: Troops dig in near Kyiv
description: Ukrainians are determined to defend their capital city as Russian troops prepare for an assault.

title: Ukraine: Mother of Russian soldier asks 'Whose door should I knock on to get my child back?'
description: Families of Russian soldiers in Ukraine tell the BBC the men had no idea what they were getting into.

title: Zimbabwe clinics struggle for nurses after exodus to the UK
description: With large numbers of nurses emigrating, patient care is suffering as there are not enough staff.

title: Private military firms see demand in Ukraine war
description: Private military contractors see surging demand in Ukraine - but could the work turn mercenary?

title: Russia-Ukraine: Is internet on verge of break-up?
description: The global internet is under threat as the conflict in Ukraine continues.

title: Ukraine: The Indian girl who wouldn’t abandon her dog in a war zone
description: Arya Aldrin undertook a gruelling journey to bring her Siberian husky to India.

title: Endurance: Underwater robots find Shackleton's lost ship
description: Video captured by underwater robots of the shipwreck shows Endurance to be in remarkable condition.

title: War in Ukraine: Ukraine maternity and children's ward in ruins after Russia strike
description: Russian forces bombed a hospital in the southern city of Mariupol, say officials in Ukraine.

title: Ukraine President Zelensky: From TV star to wartime leader
description: The Ukrainian president's journey from comedian with no political experience to convincing war leader.

title: Ukraine invasion: 'I had to leave my parents in Sumy'
description: Civilians flee the besieged Ukrainian city, parts of which have been wiped out.

title: Ukraine: Family escapes Kharkiv to Poland to treat daughter's cancer
description: After four days on the run, three-year-old Polina and her mother have made it out of Ukraine.

title: Russia's re-engagement with Africa pays off
description: Russia has been aggressively expanding its influence in Africa in recent years. As numerous African nations remain silent over Russia's invasion of Ukraine, the tactic seems to be paying off.

title: 'Tarnished' DFB set for presidential election
description: On Friday, the German Football Association will elect the new president of the world's largest sports association. The need for reform is huge and repairing a badly damaged image is the first priority.

title: COVID digest: Germany draws up framework to ease rules
description: German ministers have revealed more about their plans to ease most of the regulations to contain COVID-19 later this month. Meanwhile, Austria has dropped its law making vaccination mandatory. Follow DW for more.

title: Russia admits to use of conscripts in Ukraine invasion — live updates
description: President Zelenskyy has accused Russia of bombing a hospital in Mariupol during a supposed ceasefire to enable civilians to leave. The EU has agreed to sanction more oligarchs and officials. Follow DW for the latest.

title: Ukraine war: How a 'fact-checking' website is spreading Russian propaganda
description: A website called "War on Fakes" is using false claims made by Ukrainian outlets to disseminate Russian propaganda. DW takes a look at what and who's behind it.

title: Ukrainian Catholics in Germany overcome despair and swing into action
description: The Russian invasion of Ukraine left them bewildered and saddened – then they sprang into action. Congregations of the Ukrainian-Greek Catholic church all over Germany are helping as much as they can.

title: Scholz: Sending Polish jets to Ukraine via US base in Germany 'certainly' not an option
description: Germany and the US have both said sending Polish MiG fighters to Ukraine would be an escalatory step. Ukrainian President Zelenskyy has pleaded with NATO to provide more firepower.

title: Ukraine-Russia conflict has German teens terrified
description: War in Europe has become a reality for the first time in decades. German teens are concerned that Russia's aggression will spread beyond Ukraine.

title: First pig heart transplant recipient dies 2 months after surgery
description: The first person to receive a pig heart transplant has died, the hospital that carried out the surgery has said. David Bennett, 57, underwent the operation in January as he was ineligible for a human heart transplant.

title: DW correspondent perspectives: reporting on the war in Ukraine:
description: DW's correspondents report from Kyiv, Lviv, Chernivtsi and countries bordering Ukraine. Here is a sample of their experiences in recent days regarding the war, refugees and how the rest of Europe is responding.

title: Shackleton's shipwreck is an 'amazing' story of life
description: Finding Shackleton's ship Endurance has made history. Expedition team member Stefanie Arndt says it's also an achievement of international collaboration.

title: Middle East faces severe wheat crisis over war in Ukraine
description: Middle Eastern and North African countries rely heavily on wheat imports from Russia and Ukraine. The current war could lead to a severe food crisis in a region already under pressure.

title: Inge Deutschkron: Remembrance as a life's mission
description: Many Holocaust survivors remained silent throughout their lives — but not Inge Deutschkron. On March 9, 2022, the honorary citizen of Berlin died at the age of 99.

title: Why are India's jails so overcrowded?
description: Prison occupancy in India has been on the rise over the past five years with overcrowded jails struggling to cater to the needs of prisoners. Experts point to the mass incarceration of pre-trial prisoners.

title: Ukraine War: The role of the Orthodox Churches
description: About 75% of Russians and 60% of Ukrainians profess to be Orthodox Christians. How are their churches responding to the war?

title: Is Russia sabotaging the Iran nuclear deal over Ukraine sanctions?
description: Despite progress in the negotiations to restore the 2015 Iran nuclear deal, the accord's future is at stake after a last-minute Russian demand for an exemption from Western sanctions.

title: Ukraine: Chernobyl nuclear plant off power grid, generators running instead
description: The decommissioned Chernobyl nuclear site has been knocked off Ukraine's power grid. Operations such as water cooling to manage the heat of spent fuel at the site still require power.

title: How the world has united in song via #StandWithUkraine
description: From national anthems to rock ballads by Sting, the Scorpions or John Lennon, musicians around the globe are showing their support for Ukraine via music.

title: Opinion: Will the Ukraine war plunge the world economy into a new crisis?
description: Russia's war against Ukraine is disrupting and likely stifling the world's economic recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. What comes next is unclear, but it's not going to be any better, thinks DW's Henrik Böhme.

title: South Korea presidential vote: Exit poll shows narrow gap
description: Voters in South Korea are electing a president who will shape Asia's fourth-largest economy. An exit poll showed the conservative candidate ahead, but only narrowly.

title: Former Paralympic swimmer Theresa Goh still trying to break barriers in Singapore
description: Theresa Goh did not hide her sexuality during her swimming career in Singapore, but few have followed the path she forged. While Goh knows that time is needed, she also hopes that sport can make a difference.

title: How to circumvent state internet censorship in Russia
description: Independent media websites are blocked in Russia. But there are ways to escape Russian propaganda — and everyone can help.

title: Australia to declare fatal floods a national emergency
description: Australia is set to declare a state of national emergency after floods on the country's east coast claimed 22 lives. The new status means flood victims can receive aid quicker.

title: RECOMMENDED — From a 'Friendship Pipeline' to Nord Stream 2, Germany's relationship with Russian gas has always been complicated
description: For 50 years, Russian gas has powered German homes and businesses. From the start, the trade link was controversial, but it established deep economic ties between the two countries.

title: How war videos on social media can trigger secondary trauma
description: During a war, trauma is no longer limited to the battlefield. Violent and distressing content on social media can leave a lasting impression. Here's how users can be prepared.

title: Iraq: Rebuilding churches as symbols of hope
description: Much effort is being put into rebuilding churches that were destroyed by the "Islamic State." The message of hope is for Christians to return, and to turn Mosul into a better place than before.

title: Fleeing Russia's invasion, Ukrainians hit a wall at UK
description: As countries open borders to Ukrainians, Britain's policies, which are largely limited to family reunification, seem stingy in comparison. Through Monday, Britain had only issued about 50 visas for displaced Ukrainians.

title: Venezuela releases jailed Americans after talks with US
description: Two Americans, including a former oil executive, have been released from a Venezuelan jail after more than four years. The goodwill gesture follows a visit by a high-level US delegation to Caracas.

title: Leaving Russia on foot as Ukraine invasion unfolds
description: Once Moscow had launched its invasion of Ukraine, direct routes between Russia and the West became almost impossible to find. A few routes to the EU are still open, as DW Russia correspondent Juri Rescheto discovered.

title: Proud Boys leader charged for role in US Capitol riot
description: Enrique Tarrio was indicted Tuesday along with five other members of the far-right group. The charges are among the most serious leveled against the more than 775 suspects arrested so far.

title: Germany's far-right AfD can be put under surveillance
description: The far-right populist Alternative for Germany has lost a legal battle against the countryˈs domestic intelligence service. Judges ruled that the party can be categorized as "suspicious entity."

title: Young Russians to their parents: 'How is it possible to think differently about this war?'
description: How can young Russians change the minds of their parents, who get most of their news from state television and defend the war in Ukraine? We spoke to some who talked about heated family debates and deep divisions.

title: UN commissioner to travel to Xinjiang on long-delayed China visit
description: Human Rights Commissioner Michelle Bachelet has said the visit will take place in May. She will travel to western Xinjiang province, where rights groups say over a million Muslim Uyghurs are kept in "reeducation camps."

title: Carnival spread COVID in Cologne — again
description: The German city of Cologne’s Carnival celebrations raged on as normal late last month, barring a few restrictions. Now the city at the heart of the holiday is facing COVID-19 consequences.

title: Ukrainian international footballer Nicole Kozlova: 'I was numb to it all'
description: While Ukrainian footballer Nicole Kozlova watches on from Denmark, some of her teammates still reside in war-stricken Ukraine. Speaking with DW, she shares how she stays in touch and her hopes for the future.

title: Joe Biden bans US imports of Russian oil, gas after Ukraine's pleas
description: The US will stop importing oil and natural gas from Russia, US President Joe Biden has said as the West escalates sanctions against Moscow over the Ukraine invasion.

title: Germany's Russian community faces harassment and hostility
description: Since Russia's invasion of Ukraine began, Germans with Russian roots have been reporting aggression against them: at school, on public transport, in everyday life.

title: Football: African women are taking their chances
description: For many women trying to get into football management in Africa, there are still hurdles to leap. But DW spoke to some who are breaking down the barriers that previously kept them out of the sport's top jobs.

title: A peculiar case of age and hunger-defying African ticks
description: A US-based researcher has made an accidental discovery about longevity in a species of African ticks. The creatures live for nearly 30 years, and can go eight years without food.

title: Top Russian conductor quits over war in Ukraine
description: Top Russian conductor Thomas Sanderling has stepped down in protest against Russia's invasion of Ukraine. But he's spoken out against a boycott of Russian culture, saying artists should not be forced to pick sides.

title: The mystery of a disappearing lake and the struggle over water rights in Chile
description: When a large lagoon in central Chile dried up, climate change seemed the likeliest culprit. But researchers found a more insidious threat: systematic privatization of water. Could a new constitution change all that?

title: War in Ukraine threatens India's blockbuster IPO
description: India's behemoth state-owned insurer LIC is all set to go public with an initial public offering that is billed to be the biggest ever in India. But Russia's invasion of Ukraine has raised questions about the timing.

title: Stella Nyanzi: Uganda's radical activist
description: Nyanzi's fight for free speech, women's rights and LGBTQ+ rights has landed her in high-security prison — twice. But she remains critical of President Yoweri Museveni, even while exiled in Germany.

title: Simone de Beauvoir and 'The Second Sex'
description: A new exhibition in Bonn revisits Simone de Beauvoir's "The Second Sex." The French existentialist philosopher's book is more relevant today than ever, says German feminist Alice Schwarzer.

title: Ukraine war: Will Arab oil save the world from soaring prices?
description: Sanctions on Russia won't work unless the world reduces its use of Russian oil and gas. But it's difficult to do this without also increasing prices. Middle Eastern oil producers could help. But do they want to?

title: War in Ukraine: Commodity market chaos sends stocks falling further
description: The price of oil is spiking, commodities are at all-time highs and stock markets are on a crash course. The escalation in the Ukraine war is causing chaos on the markets — and there's no end in sight.

title: How to send messages in Ukraine if the internet shuts down
description: The Russian army is targeting Ukraine's communication and internet infrastructure. Here's how you can communicate if your internet connection has been destroyed.

title: War in Ukraine highlights vulnerability of critical energy infrastructure
description: Keeping energy supplies safe from hackers is becoming more important, as countries decarbonize their economies and modernize electricity grids.

title: Ukrainians have won the information war: historian Margaret MacMillan
description: While Russian troops continue to assault Ukrainian cities amid stiff resistance from locals, Kyiv seems to have won the battle of narratives, the Canadian author says.

title: Digital Protest: Women fighting for their rights using the power of social media
description: Women’s rights, protecting the environment, or fighting hate speech: Women worldwide are politically active online. They face online and offline abuse.

title: Culture rallies for Ukraine in Berlin
description: A "Concert for Peace" headed by star conductor Daniel Barenboim, and a later rally by literary luminaries at the site of the Nazi book burnings, bookended a day of solidarity with Ukraine.

title: Russia detains US basketball player Brittney Griner on drug charges — reports
description: Phoenix Mercury center Brittney Griner was detained at Moscow Sheremetyevo airport after officials reportedly found hashish oil in her luggage. The move comes as US-Russian diplomatic tensions increase over Ukraine.

title: Ukrainian fencer Olena Kryvytska: 'I hope to wake up without war'
description: As war rages in Ukraine, hundreds of thousands have fled their homeland while others have stayed behind. Among them is Ukrainian fencer Olena Kryvytska, who has demanded that Russian athletes speak out against the war.

title: F1: Haas ditch Mazepin and Uralkali, Russian drivers must sign FIA document
description: Formula One team Haas has parted company with driver Nikita Mazepin and sponsor Uralkali in the wake of Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Meanwhile, other Russian drivers will have to sign a Driver Commitment document.

title: How vital is nuclear energy for Ukraine?
description: When it was attacked by Russian forces, Ukraine's Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant shifted to center stage. But while nuclear energy is important to Ukraine, the country still gets 70% of its power from fossil fuels.

title: Will war fast-track the energy transition?
description: The sudden push to reduce Europe's dependence on Russian gas and oil could trigger a paradigm shift to clean energy sources that might be quickly scaled up.

title: Radiation: Does iodine help?
description: Fears have grown about radiation exposure since Russia's attack on a Ukrainian nuclear facility. But taking iodine won't always help. It can, in fact, be dangerous.

title: Russia sanctions threaten Vladimir Putin's allies in Latin America
description: The effects of the sanctions on Russia's banking system will likely affect Venezuela, Nicaragua and Cuba. Energy, military and agricultural sectors could suffer the most.

title: Europe looks to Africa to fill natural gas gap
description: To move away from depending on Russian energy, Europe is increasingly turning to Africa for its natural gas imports. Though the potential is there, low supply and serious bottlenecks stand in the way.

title: Winter Paralympic Games open in Beijing with calls for peace in Ukraine
description: The tournament starts amidst the Russian war on Ukraine that has led to the expulsion of its athletes. The Chinese government has refused to criticize Russia as it welcomed more than five hundred athletes for the Games.

title: Tesla's Germany plant almost ready to roll with final permit granted
description: US carmaker Tesla's fourth Gigafactory has received a long-awaited final permit from regional German authorities. But full-scale production has to start later due to the strings attached.

title: Ukraine's little-known space feats
description: The war in Ukraine threatens space development — and not only due to sanctions on Russia. Ukraine plays a little-known, but crucial, role in the world's space scene.

title: Ukraine: How to protect yourself against cyberattacks
description: Cyberattacks are an emerging weapon of choice in the ongoing Russia-Ukraine war and could have spillover effects across the world. Though difficult to predict, they can be managed with proper preparation.

title: From COVID to Ukraine: How do I explain it to my kids?
description: COVID is far from over and already there's a new crisis: War in Ukraine. That's on top of the climate crisis. What do we tell the kids? Here are some tips.

title: Ukraine: The risks of war in a nuclear state
description: The fear that Russia's invasion of Ukraine could escalate to a nuclear war is real. But what happens now that its largest active nuclear power plant has been caught in the crossfire?

title: Do cryptocurrencies offer Russians a way round sanctions?
description: Since a wave of financial sanctions hit Russia over its Ukraine invasion, questions have been raised over whether cryptocurrencies could provide an escape route. But leading exchanges said they will comply with the law.

title: Does Germany really need LNG terminals?
description: The German government now aims to build liquefied natural gas terminals to become less dependent on Russian gas. But are they really a sound investment, given the need for climate-friendly energy?

title: Ukraine: Cyberwar creates chaos, 'it won't win the war'
description: There have been at least 150 cyberattacks in Ukraine since Russia's invasion. Their effect is mainly psychological, and experts say they won't decide the war.

title: Opinion: Turning the tide on plastic pollution
description: Plastic pollution is pushing our health and ecosystems to the brink of disaster, but the global agreement to tackle the issue offers hope, writes Christina Dixon of Environmental Investigation Agency.

title: Germany's army: Will €100 billion make it strong?
description: Following the Russian attack on Ukraine, Germany has decided to dramatically beef up its defense budget and give the Bundeswehr an extra €100 billion. What will it use the money for?

title: Sanctions on Russia: Death by a thousand cuts
description: Western sanctions imposed on Russia as a reaction to its invasion of Ukraine are beginning to bite. Everybody is likely to be affected, but some economic sectors will be hit harder than others.

title: Plastic: World agrees to tackle the crisis
description: The petrochemical industry is pumping out polluting plastic faster than ever. The UN has made a groundbreaking pledge to try to end the "epidemic" of plastic pollution.

title: How a teenager's Twitter tracks Russian oligarchs
description: A college student who's been tracking Elon Musk's plane is now also posting the movements of Russian oligarchs on Twitter. The thing is: almost anyone can do it.

title: Ukraine crisis forces Germany to change course on energy
description: Germany's energy dependence on Russia is enormous. Will nuclear power plants have to operate longer and the coal phase-out have to be postponed? Some see fresh opportunities in the current crisis.

title: How could Russia sanctions impact you?
description: Western sanctions are threatening to send the Russian economy into a tailspin. The tremors of the sanctions would be felt across the world from Africa to Europe in the form of higher inflation and food shortages.

title: Will Musk's Starlink save Ukraine, SpaceX save the ISS?
description: Tech tycoon Elon Musk has indicated he will protect the internet in Ukraine and the world from the International Space Station if it crashes to Earth. But how?

title: Opinion: Time to rethink climate adaptation
description: A major new report highlights the need for humans to stop climate change in order to protect their own well-being. DW's Heather Moore says it's time to listen.

title: IPCC depicts unfolding climate emergency
description: The latest Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change report details a widespread climate catastrophe, along with ways to address — and fund — adaptation and resilience in vulnerable regions.

title: How can I reduce my gas consumption?
description: Gas prices have risen to record levels in recent months — and the Russian invasion of Ukraine won't help matters, especially in Europe. What can we do to reduce our dependence on natural gas?

title: Does this picture tell the real story of corporate Germany?
description: A picture from the Munich Security Conference commanded global attention, yet it had nothing to do with the Ukraine conflict. For many, the all-male "CEO Lunch" photo represents the reality of corporate Germany.

title: 'Superlative' pterosaur, world's biggest mid-Jurassic flying animal, found in Scotland
description: A skeleton of the biggest animal to have flown during the Middle Jurassic was discovered on the Isle of Skye, Scotland. This is one of the best-preserved fossils in UK's history, researchers who found it told DW.

title: COVID: Sanofi-GSK ask regulators to approve new protein-based vaccine
description: Creators of a new protein-based coronavirus vaccine say it is 100% effective at preventing severe illness and hospitalization.

title: Can cryptocurrency ever be environmentally friendly?
description: A Costa Rican hydropower plant has transformed into a green crypto-mining operation. But can energy-hungry cryptocurrencies such as bitcoin ever be compatible with climate targets?

title: France and China link up in global infrastructure projects
description: Paris and Beijing have agreed to build infrastructure projects in Africa, South East Asia and Eastern Europe. But will this help shine light on China’s opaque foreign investments? Or just give the appearance of doing so?

title: COVID: Is England scrapping self-isolation too soon?
description: England is ditching self-isolation for positive COVID-19 cases, leaving scientists concerned about variants, the spread of the coronavirus and sick people being forced to work.

title: Wildfires to increase up to 30% by 2050, experts warn
description: The intense, destructive fires that have dominated headlines in recent years are expected to become more frequent, even in places like the Arctic. Experts warn our response must shift toward planning and preparedness.

title: BioNTainers and co: The disjointed quest to produce COVID mRNA vaccines in Africa
description: The European Union-African Union summit brought dissonant news about COVID-19 mRNA vaccine development in Africa, revealing cracks in collaboration between the world's largest drug companies and the WHO.

title: Can genetic engineering make meat sustainable?
description: Climate-friendly sheep and salmon that eat less yet grow faster. Researchers are using genetic engineering to design animals for the livestock farming of the future.

title: 25 years of Dolly: What’s become of the world’s first cloned sheep?
description: Dolly the infamous sheep was cloned 25 years ago. Since then, major progress has been made in stem cell research. And lots of other animals have been cloned ― including, yes, pets.

title: How the climate crisis is threatening our energy supply
description: Whether it's heat or heavy rain, the consequences of climate change are putting our energy security at risk. Oil, gas and nuclear energy are particularly vulnerable. So what does that mean for our future?

title: Cryptocurrency and football's perfect match causes concerns
description: The worlds of professional football and cryptocurrency have become increasingly enmeshed over the past year. Critics say it is reckless that the game has got so tied up with the unregulated, volatile sector.

title: Ethiopia grapples with severe drought
description: Nearly 7 million people in Ethiopia's drought-hit regions need urgent help after a third failed rainy season devastates pastoralist communities.

title: Your car hosts more bacteria than your toilet seat, research shows
description: It's easy to understand why toilets are gross. But cars may be worse. A study has found that cars can host more germs than the average toilet seat.

title: Lingering colonial legacies: The study of skin is too white
description: The historical lack of racial representation in dermatology textbooks isn't just a problem in countries with majority white populations, but across the globe.

title: Period products: How menstruation is managed around the world
description: In the early 20th century, rags were used to manage periods. Since then, lots of options have been developed to make menstruating far more comfortable. But many across the world are still "on the rag" — literally.

title: Experts say falling in love is great but watch your heart
description: Experts say that falling in love enhances your well-being. But they stress the importance of watching your heart while doing so, especially for older people with blood vessel blockages or heart attack survivors.

title: Cocoa farming for forest conservation in Ghana
description: Cocoa cultivated in Ghana's forests is encroaching on natural ecosystems. Boosting the productivity of existing plantations could keep their expansion in check.

title: Chinese 'space cleaner' spotted grabbing and throwing away old satellite
description: Last month, a private satellite tracking company spotted a Chinese spacecraft apparently grabbing and throwing a dead satellite away into a "graveyard" orbit.

title: COVID: Chinese researchers develop 4-minute PCR test
description: Researchers at Fudan University in Shanghai say they have developed a technology combining the speed of the rapid antigen test with the accuracy of PCR testing.

title: Live Updates: Costs of War Mount for Russia, and for Civilians in Ukraine
description: Russia’s Central Bank limited withdrawals of foreign currency, hoping to shore up the plunging ruble as Western economic penalties take a serious toll. In Ukraine, efforts to evacuate civilians from battered cities resumed, but many remain trapped in the areas of heaviest fighting.

title: Live Updates: South Korea Presidential Race Too Close to Call
description: With less than one-tenth of ballots still to be tallied, Yoon Suk-yeol, the conservative candidate, had a slim lead over his liberal rival, Lee Jae-myung, early Thursday.

title: Russia’s Other Contest With the West: Economic Endurance
description: Which side can maintain domestic support as the war costs regular citizens could also determine the outcome in Ukraine.

title: Assassinated in His Prime, an Iconic African Leader Haunts a Trial and His Country
description: Thirty-five years after the killing of President Thomas Sankara of Burkina Faso, his supporters hope for justice. But the full truth about the murder, including any foreign role, is elusive.

title: Australia Flooding Declared a National Emergency
description: At least 20 people have died and tens of thousands have been ordered to evacuate as record rainfall continues to inundate the country’s eastern coast.

title: Hong Kong's Covid Crackdown Empties Stores and Sets Off Exodus
description: A surge in cases has alarmed many residents. But the government’s mixed messaging about whether it will impose a lockdown has also been destabilizing.

title: Mexican Women Protest Femicides as President Warns Against Violence
description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador has been accused of not doing enough to stem the rise in violence against women.

title: How Russia’s War in Ukraine Complicates the Iran Nuclear Deal
description: With the world eager to wean itself from Russian oil after the invasion of Ukraine, negotiators appeared close to signing a revived nuclear pact with Iran and lifting sanctions. Then Moscow put up a hurdle.

title: Meet South Korea’s Swing Voters: Young, Broke and Angry
description: Frustrated over housing prices, a lack of job opportunities and a widening income gap, the once-reliable voting bloc is undecided and will most likely elect the next president.

title: Venezuela Releases Imprisoned Americans After Talks With U.S.
description: The release of Gustavo Cárdenas, an executive at the U.S. branch of Venezuela’s state oil company, and Jorge Alberto Fernández came after Biden officials moved to thaw relations with Venezuela, long a steadfast Russian ally.

title: As Fighting Gets Closer, a Kyiv Hospital Treats the War’s Atrocities
description: As Russian bombings have grown more indiscriminate, hospitals in Ukraine have become perilous places to work.

title: ​South Korea’s Presidential Election: What to Watch
description: ​After a campaign marred by scandals and mudslinging, the country is set to elect its next president amid widespread voter discontent.

title: Two Days of Russian News Coverage: An Alternate Reality of War
description: To watch news broadcasts of the fighting in Ukraine on the main state channels in Russia is to witness the extent of the Kremlin’s efforts to sanitize its war.

title: Moldova Fears It May Be Russia’s Next Target
description: Moldova has taken in more Ukrainians, per capita, than any other country. But the closer Russian troops get to Moldova, the more locals consider their own escape plans.

title: Ukrainians Trying to Flee to U.K. Face a Confounding Path
description: The government has offered a way for U.K. residents to bring over Ukrainian relatives fleeing the war. But families and rights groups say it’s a bureaucratic nightmare that makes it too difficult to get in.

title: With Humor, and a Nod to History, Johnson and Zelensky Find a Rapport
description: Forging an alliance with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine was a natural for Boris Johnson, Britain’s prime minister. The two share a sense of the moment.

title: No Ikea Shelves, No Levis: The Western Retail Exodus From Russia Is On
description: Since the invasion of Ukraine began, the increasing financial and reputational risks of doing business in Russia is leading Western brands to halt operations.

title: Power Loss at Chernobyl Is Worrying, but Not an Immediate Threat, U.N. Says
description: The International Atomic Energy Agency said that it saw “no critical impact on safety” at this time because the amount of cooling water was sufficient.

title: How Redlining Contributed to Air Pollution Across America
description: A new study shows how redlining, a Depression-era housing policy, contributed to inequalities that persist decades later in U.S. cities.

title: Olena Zelenska, Ukraine’s First Lady, Condemns Russia’s Invasion
description: Olena Zelenska says in a letter that Russian forces are engaged in the “mass murder of civilians” and reiterates her husband’s call for a no-fly zone.

title: Do Covid Precautions Work?
description: Yes, but they haven’t made a big difference.

title: ‘We Wanted to Be in Combat Zones. We Were as Courageous as the Men.’
description: A new exhibition in Paris spotlights the work of eight female photographers who documented wars over the course of 75 years.

title: How the War in Ukraine Is Affecting Travel
description: How travelers feel the effects of Russia’s assault on Ukraine depends largely on where they’re going, though the price of oil will weigh on all airfares, even domestic.

title: Who is Lee Jae Myung, the Liberal Candidate in South Korea’s Election?
description: His challenge is to promise continuity with the ruling party’s policies, yet distinguish himself from the current president.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Western moves to isolate Russia.

title: Who Is Yoon Suk-yeol?
description: Mr. Yoon, the leading conservative candidate, hopes to win the election by appealing to South Koreans who are deeply dissatisfied with the outgoing administration.

title: Biden Bans Oil Imports From Russia, Warning Gas Prices Will Rise
description: Officials said President Biden had struggled for days over the move amid deep concerns about accelerating the already rapid rise in the price of gasoline.

title: Zelensky Vows No Surrender in Video to Britain’s Parliament
description: In a dramatic video address to Britain’s House of Commons, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said he would never capitulate to the invading Russians.

title: U.S. Intelligence Tells Congress Putin Is ‘Unlikely to Be Deterred’
description: Top U.S. intelligence officials told Congress that the Russian leader had underestimated Ukrainian resolve and Western cohesion but was “doubling down” to achieve his goals.

title: Starbucks, McDonald’s and Others Pause Operations in Russia
description: After years of cultivating the Russian market, McDonald’s, Starbucks, PepsiCo and Coca-Cola said they would temporarily close locations or stop selling products there.

title: W.H.O. Bolsters Booster Endorsement but Still Emphasizes More Primary Shots
description: The broad endorsement comes as the W.H.O.’s stance on boosters continues to evolve.

title: Brittney Griner’s WNBA Impact Is Clear As Fans Await Word from Russia
description: Griner, one of the world’s best basketball players, was believed to have been detained in Russia on what customs officials described as drug charges. Fans are worried.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Biden Bans Russian Oil
description: Plus South Korea is set to elect a new president and Afghan smugglers flourish.

title: ‘Cabaret,’ Starring Eddie Redmayne, Leads Olivier Award Nominees
description: A revival of the 1966 musical, with Jessie Buckley as Sally Bowles, is up for 11 awards at Britain’s equivalent of the Tonys.

title: ‘Kony 2012,’ 10 Years Later
description: Once the most viral video of all time, the film reads as both a digital relic and a precursor to an era in which footage of conflict dominates the internet.

title: Biden Bans All Imports of Russian Oil Into U.S.
description: The British also said they would phase out imports of Russian oil by the end of the year to increase the economic isolation of Russia’s president, Vladimir. V. Putin.

title: Here are the latest developments in the war in Ukraine.
U.N. Human Rights Chief to Visit China
description: Michelle Bachelet would be the first official in her position to visit China, which has come under fire for its rights record, in nearly two decades.

title: W.H.O. Condemns Attacks on Health Care Services in Ukraine, Calls for Safe Passage for Medical Supplies
description: The organization has confirmed at least 16 attacks on the medical system, which is facing urgent supply shortages.

title: What Ukrainian Military Reports Are Saying Nearly 2 Weeks Into War
description: The Ukrainian military claims to have killed thousands of Russian soldiers and destroyed hundreds of tanks and aircraft. Verifying the figures is challenging.

title: China’s Russia Problem
description: Things were going very well for China, until the war in Ukraine.

title: How Maori Stepped In to Save a Towering Tree Crucial to Their Identity
description: Tāne Mahuta, an ancient tree named after the god of forests in Māori mythology, is threatened by the slow creep of an incurable disease.

title: The Smugglers’ Paradise of Afghanistan
description: For decades, the smuggling trade — of people, drugs and money — has dominated Nimruz Province. Now, as hundreds of thousands of Afghans try to flee, business has further boomed for those who hold the keys to the gate.

title: Poles Welcome Ukrainian Refugees, Unlike in Last Border Crisis
description: Hundreds of thousands of Polish families have opened their homes to refugees from Ukraine, a sharp contrast to the country’s response to a different crisis last fall at the border with Belarus.

title: A 459-Foot Mystery in a Tuscan Port: Is It a Russian’s Superyacht?
description: As European authorities go after the luxury assets of oligarchs close to Vladimir Putin, a superyacht cloaked in secrecy has come under investigation.

title: Venezuela Could Be Fill-in for Russian Oil, But Critics Fear Aiding Maduro
description: U.S. officials are reportedly considering easing sanctions on Venezuelan crude as oil prices have skyrocketed.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: An intensifying humanitarian crisis in Ukraine.

title: Moderna opens the door to enforcing its vaccine patents in some countries.
description: The company had previously pledged not to enforce its Covid vaccine patents anywhere during the pandemic.

title: Allowed to go maskless, some New York City students choose not to.
Video: Zelensky Is Seen in His Office for  First Time Since Invasion
description: The Ukrainian president told his people that he was not afraid or in hiding.

title: As Russia’s Military Stumbles, Its Adversaries Take Note
description: President Vladimir Putin could still reduce cities in Ukraine to rubble, officials say. But European countries say they are not as intimidated by Russian ground forces as they were in the past.

title: Humanitarian Crisis Worsens for Ukrainians Trapped in Russia’s Onslaught
description: Two weeks after the invasion began, tens of thousands of Ukrainians are without food, water or power. The Russians are increasingly resorting to indiscriminate shelling to help their forces advance.

title: Biden Officials Weigh Russian Oil Ban as Gas Prices Soar
description: Global stocks dipped on Monday as U.S. officials discussed an oil cutoff, and gas prices hit a national average above $4, up more than 10 percent in a week.

title: Risks to the Brain
description: Covid-19 may cause  tissue damage and loss of gray matter

title: Once Victims in Southeast Europe, Jews Come to Aid Fleeing Ukrainians
description: Today, as in the early 1900s, Jews are once again escaping violence in southeast Europe. But the context is radically different — cathartically so for the many Israelis who have come here to join the relief effort.

title: Letter ‘Z,’ Symbol of Support for War, Spreads Across Russia
description: The letter, painted on Russian military vehicles, is suddenly ubiquitous in Russia, prompting talk of a Kremlin public relations campaign.

title: Baltics, in Russia's Shadow, Demand Tougher Stance From West
description: “We have no illusions about Putin’s Russia anymore,” said one Baltic official in a meeting with the U.S. secretary of state.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Russia escalates attacks on civilians
description: Plus new research warning of a drier Amazon and Xi’s relationship with Putin.

title: Against C.D.C. Advice, Florida to Advise Against Covid Vaccines for Healthy Children
description: The C.D.C. has urged parents to get their eligible children vaccinated. “Covid-19 can make children very sick and cause children to be hospitalized,” the agency’s website says.

title: 9/11 Suspect Is Returned to Saudi Arabia for Mental Health Care
description: Mohammed al-Qahtani had spent 20 years at Guantánamo Bay, where he was tortured so badly that he was ineligible to be tried at the war crimes court.
